data.text: @khurramn1 @WofaKay_Hagan @thehowie @SaadOmer3 @BhadeliaMD @PeterHotez @MethodistHosp @WHO @WHCOVIDResponse @HoustonChron @TCTMD Proud to join @khurramn1 et al in exploring composite indicators of #SDoH & their application to #COVID19 & #CVD @MethodistHosp @GWpublichealth @CCDH_GWSPH

#8
Our collective well summarized by @WofaKay_Hagan 

"Unless we look at COVID-19 through the lens of social determinants of health, we may not optimize our yield from interventions, and we might not be reaching the group of individuals who need these interventions the most" 👇 https://t.co/sPkIa9hECi

#7 
In adjusted models, a higher SDOH burden was associated with a lower likelihood of adhering to all measures of each broad mitigation strategy https://t.co/q8TUX2QhwE

#6 
Those most vulnerable less likely to practice all personal protection measures (75.6% vs 89.0%),  social distancing measures (41.9% vs 58.9%), and affording at least one flexible work schedule (26.2% vs 41.4%) https://t.co/lVyxvNL6W7

#5
An accumulative #SDOH index/score using twelve factors across six SDOH domains from the Kaiser Family Foundation SDOH framework

The domains are economic stability, neighborhood/physical environment, education, food, community/social context, and health care system https://t.co/ZB0QYQ2swI

#4 @WofaKay_Hagan sought out https://t.co/R0Ww9nWDzr (COVID Impact Survey) to classify ability to pursue 
-Personal protection strategy
-Social distancing strategy
-Work flexibility 
https://t.co/R0Ww9nWDzr https://t.co/dR3OHXgNGL

#3
We were inspired by @NMHheartdoc sobering reminder last summer that mitigation measures that may seem "simple" to us such as social distancing, masking and affording work flexibility may indeed be a "social privilege", and may not be able to afford it 
https://t.co/8TBfG9UOQF https://t.co/wAo9ICcE3k

The study now simultaneously published @CircOutcomes 

Link below for the full study  
https://t.co/UqWko9BkHV https://t.co/Y9f1HmFpRP
